entry.value: This page features more of the different types of data copy available in Rapid.

Following on from our last page on data copying, this page will use the same grid and data from the previous page, so there are no surprises. The grid will begin with all of the same data as well. This page will cover the remaining data copy types, however some are a lot more advanced and complicated than others, so if you don't quite understand it on the first run through do not worry.

To resume our coverage on data copies we will be exploring bulk data copies. Bulk data copies offer all of the simple data copy types, but in a more compact manner. This is very ideal for when we come across the need for multiple data copies and want to save event space. Clicking on the 'Populate grid' button will take information from the inputs below and will add them to the grid. This may seem familiar, and it should, however behind the scenes the way in which this is all done is a lot more compact and efficient!

Moving on from the bulk data copy, the child data copy works in a more complicated way to the other data copies we have covered so far. Child merging will talk to data inside of data, so for example if we have
Child merging works in a unique way. It talks to data inside of data. Think of it like tabular data inside of tabular data, or in a more programming sense we have a master class that talks to a parent class that talks to a child class!
helpHtml: Will use fields in common between the source and destination to match rows in the source to rows in the destination where matching rows in the source will be added to child datastores in the destination. Use this for parent/child relationships.

Furthering from the child data copy action, we now be looking at the search data copy. This data copy type is quite a quirky one. It allows you to search for a source against a matching term and if a match is found then all matching rows will have their data copied in to.

Finishing up our complicated data copy types is the transpose data copy. This data copy type works best with row merges and datastores. The premise of the transpose data copy is that it will swap row data and column data around. It is mostly useful for highly normalised databases and surveys. When used with databases data can be pulled out in a de-normalised fashion, but stored in a normalised fashion.

[{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P7_C151_","text":"The bulk data copy is a brilliant way of compressing large amounts of different, simple data copies into a single group. Whilst amazingly compact, you will be limited to row merging, replacing and appending when using bulk data copies. In a lot of cases, when using data copying, you will find you are using a lot of the basic types frequently and often, which is where the bulk data copy shines. It works extremely well when used in combination with the existing action type in Rapid. This allows you to replay the same effects of another action that has already been pre-defined!","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P7_C202_","text":"The search data copy excels at returning data based on what a user searches, providing a match is found. The example we've used here searches for a surname in the grid's data. If a match is found then we have multiple destinations for the data, with an accompanying key to go with it. The result of this is that all of the details are returned into the app from the grid! If no result is found then the search results are emptied.","type":"hover"}]

{"controlHints":[{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P7_C151_","text":"The bulk data copy is a brilliant way of compressing large amounts of different, simple data copies into a single group. Whilst amazingly compact, you will be limited to row merging, replacing and appending when using bulk data copies. In a lot of cases, when using data copying, you will find you are using a lot of the basic types frequently and often, which is where the bulk data copy shines. It works extremely well when used in combination with the existing action type in Rapid. This allows you to replay the same effects of another action that has already been pre-defined!","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P7_C202_","text":"The search data copy excels at returning data based on what a user searches, providing a match is found. The example we've used here searches for a surname in the grid's data. If a match is found then we have multiple destinations for the data, with an accompanying key to go with it. The result of this is that all of the details are returned into the app from the grid! If no result is found then the search results are emptied.","type":"hover"}]}

query.SQL: select forename, surname, birthday, gender from people where id > 3 and id < 15 or id > 99 and id < 111 order by RANDOM()

page.htmlBody:
This page features more of the different types of data copy available in Rapid.

Following on from our last page on data copying, this page will use the same grid and data from the previous page, so there are no surprises. The grid will begin with all of the same data as well. This page will cover the remaining data copy types, however some are a lot more advanced and complicated than others, so if you don't quite understand it on the first run through do not worry.To resume our coverage on data copies we will be exploring bulk data copies. Bulk data copies offer all of the simple data copy types, but in a more compact manner. This is very ideal for when we come across the need for multiple data copies and want to save event space. Clicking on the 'Populate grid' button will take information from the inputs below and will add them to the grid. This may seem familiar, and it should, however behind the scenes the way in which this is all done is a lot more compact and efficient!
First name
Last name
Birthday
Gender
Moving on from the bulk data copy, the child data copy works in a more complicated way to the other data copies we have covered so far. Child merging will talk to data inside of data, so for example if we have Child merging works in a unique way. It talks to data inside of data. Think of it like tabular data inside of tabular data, or in a more programming sense we have a master class that talks to a parent class that talks to a child class! helpHtml: Will use fields in common between the source and destination to match rows in the source to rows in the destination where matching rows in the source will be added to child datastores in the destination. Use this for parent/child relationships.
First name
Last name
Birthday
Gender
Furthering from the child data copy action, we now be looking at the search data copy. This data copy type is quite a quirky one. It allows you to search for a source against a matching term and if a match is found then all matching rows will have their data copied in to.
Last name
First name
Last name
Birthday
Gender
Finishing up our complicated data copy types is the transpose data copy. This data copy type works best with row merges and datastores. The premise of the transpose data copy is that it will swap row data and column data around. It is mostly useful for highly normalised databases and surveys. When used with databases data can be pulled out in a de-normalised fashion, but stored in a normalised fashion.
First name
Last name
Birthday
Gender
ForenameSurnameBirthdayGender
Primary data copy page
page.name: 05_dataCopyTypes2

rolesHtml.html:
This page features more of the different types of data copy available in Rapid.

Following on from our last page on data copying, this page will use the same grid and data from the previous page, so there are no surprises. The grid will begin with all of the same data as well. This page will cover the remaining data copy types, however some are a lot more advanced and complicated than others, so if you don't quite understand it on the first run through do not worry.To resume our coverage on data copies we will be exploring bulk data copies. Bulk data copies offer all of the simple data copy types, but in a more compact manner. This is very ideal for when we come across the need for multiple data copies and want to save event space. Clicking on the 'Populate grid' button will take information from the inputs below and will add them to the grid. This may seem familiar, and it should, however behind the scenes the way in which this is all done is a lot more compact and efficient!
First name
Last name
Birthday
Gender
Moving on from the bulk data copy, the child data copy works in a more complicated way to the other data copies we have covered so far. Child merging will talk to data inside of data, so for example if we have Child merging works in a unique way. It talks to data inside of data. Think of it like tabular data inside of tabular data, or in a more programming sense we have a master class that talks to a parent class that talks to a child class! helpHtml: Will use fields in common between the source and destination to match rows in the source to rows in the destination where matching rows in the source will be added to child datastores in the destination. Use this for parent/child relationships.
First name

Birthday
Gender
Furthering from the child data copy action, we now be looking at the search data copy. This data copy type is quite a quirky one. It allows you to search for a source against a matching term and if a match is found then all matching rows will have their data copied in to.
Last name
First name
Last name
Birthday
Gender
Finishing up our complicated data copy types is the transpose data copy. This data copy type works best with row merges and datastores. The premise of the transpose data copy is that it will swap row data and column data around. It is mostly useful for highly normalised databases and surveys. When used with databases data can be pulled out in a de-normalised fashion, but stored in a normalised fashion.

page.title: Data copy types
